text: in the way that we're all sort of
obsessed with this idea of pitting
humans against machines I just wonder
why why you think that is and if it if
if we're afraid of the idea of them
overtaking us right I think when people
watched I know when I watched Gary you
know lose and the idea people like right
this moment of like oh no what does that
mean and I think there's a couple of
things first of all we're hierarchical
creatures by nature that's the kind of
social system that we've evolved to
manage our mutual dependencies and needs
so we think a lot about hierarchies
right and we think about where we are on
the hierarchy of creatures and for a
very long time humans assumed that above
us could only be angels or gods but in
the in the material universe there was
just us right and then we began to ask
questions about for example forms of
higher animal intelligence non-human
animals that might have intellectual
capacities of their own so that's been
fascinating to people for for as long as
we've been able to understand that
possibility the possibility of
intelligences from other parts of the
universe right has long been something
that we've contemplated and if they
arrived would they overtake us would
they
out-compete us would they where would
they be on our hierarchy and so I think
the story of artificial intelligence
just fits into this long-standing
fascination that we have with our own
position in the world and we've long
seen our intelligence as the thing that
gives us that hierarchical status power
entitlement and I think the idea of a
machine that could have those capacities
that seems both attractive and
potentially threatening
